In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  the  result  of  2  years  of  consultation1 led  by  the 
Government of Tajikistan, Asian Development Bank (ADB), European Bank for Reconstruction 
and Development, and World Bank in the context of the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience 
(PPCR).2 The  outcome  of  the  consultation  was  Tajikistan’s  Strategic  Program  for  Climate 
Resilience (SPCR), including four investment projects and the two capacity building activities 
described in the proposed TA. The SPCR aligns with national priorities indicated in the country 
partnership strategy.3 The proposed TA is included in the country operations business plan.4 
The nature and scope of the TA were discussed with stakeholders and development partners 
during  three  consultation  missions  fielded  from  August  to  October  2011.  The  government 
concurred  with  the  TA  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  cost,  implementation  and  financing 
arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants. The TA design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Tajikistan is one of the Central Asian countries most vulnerable to climate change.6 In 
recognition of its high vulnerability, Tajikistan was chosen as one of the nine countries to 
participate in the PPCR. The expert group7 established under the PPCR to select developing 
countries around the world ranked Tajikistan very high for its vulnerability to climate-induced 
disasters based on indicators  of expected mortality and economic losses. The capacity of 
institutions, communities, and individuals to adapt to climate change was rated very low, based 
on the Human Development Index8 and other indicators related to water and food security. A 
recent study carried out by ADB and the Government of Tajikistan in the context of the PPCR 9 
shows that since the 1980s higher temperatures, decreased snowfall, droughts, avalanches, 
landslides, rock falls, and violent winds have routinely destroyed crops and infrastructure and, in 
the worst cases, taken lives. The projected rise in average temperature of up to 2oC by 2050 will 
cause glacial melt and early snow melt, changing the seasonality of runoff and affecting the 
stability of water supplies for agriculture, hydropower, and human consumption. More frequent 
drought, catastrophic flooding due to glacier lake outbursts, the destabilization of mountain 
slopes, and more frequent landslides will progressively incur economic losses, pose risks to the 
population, and hamper the ability of communities to rise out of poverty. These adverse effects 
will be compounded by projected 67% population growth10 during the 21st century and will 
exacerbate  underlying  socioeconomic  and  environmental  constraints:  land  degradation, 
crumbling infrastructure, the increasing feminization of poverty, unsustainable debt, and limited 
institutional capacity.

3.  Recent assessments and consultations carried out under the PPCR show that gaps in 
the understanding of climate risks, combined with the limited adaptive capacity of individuals 
and institutions, prevent Tajikistan from effectively anticipating and managing climate change.11 
Two main constraints were identified. First, data and information on current climate variability; 
future climate change; and its impacts on communities, infrastructure, and ecosystems are 
inadequate  to  inform  decision  making.  Inadequate  equipment  for  data  collection,  limited 
resources for acquiring and maintaining equipment, the inadequacy of technical staff capacity, 
and salaries too low to retain trained staff hinder the ability of responsible agencies to generate, 
store, and analyze climate data to produce information for decision makers. While current 
initiatives address the need to improve the infrastructure for data collection, the use of data for 
weather forecasting and climate modeling is extremely limited.12 Access to climate information is 
inadequate to support measures to reduce the adverse effects of climate change on priority 
sectors such as water resource management, energy, rural development, transport, and health. 
Women’s access to climate information is poor, and information is often provided in ways 
inappropriate for them. Education and training on how to use the available data are insufficient 
to provide a sustained skill pool for weather forecasting and modeling. 
 
4.  Second, climate change risks are not integrated into development plans. Development 
projects in key sectors do not consider climate change risks, and nothing is being done to 
facilitate  such  transformational  change  in  development  planning.  Most  public  officials  are 
unfamiliar  with  climate  proofing,  risk  screening  tools,  and  economic  analysis  of  climate 
adaptation options, which are required to prioritize and budget adaptation measures. Public 
awareness of climate change is increasing but remains low in local government agencies, 
particularly among women.13 The government and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) alike 
lack  adequate  skills  pools  to  support  the  implementation  of  such  structural  measures  as 
physical construction to reduce the possible impacts of hazards such as drought and flooding, 
or of nonstructural measures such as instituting building codes, laws on land-use planning, and 
public awareness programs. As a result, development projects cannot be formulated to consider 
design and engineering features that respond to climate change risks. Overlapping mandates 
among agencies, inadequate coordination, meager fund flows, and weak resource allocation 
mechanisms are major impediments to the effective management of climate change risks. No 
clear strategies or plans with targets and sources of funding exist to deal with climate change 
risks. The monitoring and evaluation of current climate change policies and projects are absent. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
5.  This TA will enhance planning capacity for climate change adaptation nationally and 
locally in vulnerable sectors and populations. In line with ADB’s commitment under the PPCR, 
ADB will administer the SPCR components on climate modeling and science and on building 
capacity for climate resilience.14 The climate science and modeling component will (i) enhance 
capacity to develop climate change models and interpret the outputs from those models to 
inform decision making, (ii) develop a management information system for climate data, (iii) train 
local experts, and (iv) introduce climate science and glaciology modules in institutions of higher 
education. The component for building capacity for climate resilience will (i) strengthen climate

A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact will be Tajikistan’s increased resilience to climate variability and climate 
change. By 2022, the number of households affected and the economic losses resulting from 
drought, flooding, and landslides will be reduced by 20% from the 2011 baseline. The outcome 
will be national policies and development programs incorporating safeguards to address the 
effects of climate change. By 2016, 25% of approved projects in irrigation, flood protection, 
transport, energy, and water supply and sanitation will be climate-proofed, up from a 2011 
baseline of 0%. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  Output 1 will make climate change information available to multiple users, producing 
timely and reliable information on weather and climate that can be easily accessed by national 
and more local decision makers. In coordination with ongoing activities administered by the 
World Bank,17 a climate modeling facility will be established in the State Hydrometeorological 
Services (Hydromet) Forecast Department, procuring the hardware and software necessary to 
apply high-resolution forecasting and dynamical modeling techniques18 and interpret the outputs 
from those models. The facility will be handed over to the government upon TA completion, in 
line  with  the  provisions  and  budgetary  allocation  indicated  in  the  State  Program  for  the 
Monitoring  of  Glaciers19 and  related  decrees.  A  management  information  system  will  be 
established to store and share existing and newly generated data, including disaster risks. 
Training on how to generate and use climate data and information will be provided to local 
experts who are already involved with hydro-meteorological data measurement and to the new 
experts engaged by the Hydromet under the State Program for the Monitoring of Glaciers. 
Additional  technical  skills  will  be  gained through  higher  education  curricula  enhanced  with 
climate science and glaciology modules. The climate modeling facility will gradually be handed 
over  to  the  government  and  fully  supported  with  national  budget  after  TA  completion,  in 
alignment with the state program. Options will be explored for generating income by marketing 
weather forecast and climate information services.  
 
8.  Output 2 will integrate climate change risks into Tajikistan’s development planning and 
implementation of development projects. It will develop tools and guidelines to climate-proof 
investment projects and incorporate climate change risk management in operational policies.20  
Government departments will be supported in their reviewing and updating of planning and

A national climate change adaptation strategy will be developed to identify priorities for climate 
adaptation investment projects that may be financed by development partners. Local adaptation 
plans  will  be  formulated  in  up  to  five  vulnerable  districts  selected  by  the  Committee  of 
Environmental Protection (COEP) and supported through a small grant facility to facilitate the 
participation of community organizations, NGOs, and vulnerable groups such as women. The 
small  grant  facility  will  be  able  to  support  activities  that  identify  key  climate  change 
vulnerabilities and prioritize adaptation measures through participatory approaches, the training 
of  community-based  organizations  and  local  NGOs,  and  dedicated  advisory  services  on 
adaptation. The COEP and the PPCR secretariat will facilitate the inclusion of lessons learned 
and knowledge into a risk management system supported by the national budget to ensure that 
development  projects  are  screened  for  climate  change  risks  and  that  climate  change  risk 
management is systematically incorporated into technical guidelines and sector policy. 
 
9.  Output 3 will develop and apply knowledge management systems for climate change, 
establishing systems for storing and sharing knowledge on the impacts of climate change in key 
sectors and on potential national and more local adaptation measures. By TA completion, 
government  and  other  stakeholders  will  have  deeper  knowledge  of  and  more  access  to 
information on climate change risks and adaptation options in Tajikistan. The general public, 
including  remote  communities,  will  be  able  to  use  the  knowledge  to  choose  their  coping 
strategies. Women and other disadvantaged groups will have better access to information about 
adaptation options and the support available to assist them in implementing those changes. The 
PPCR secretariat will be able to manage and disseminate knowledge to address the needs of 
stakeholders. 
 
10.  Output 4 will ensure that the other outputs of the PPCR are managed for results. It will 
monitor the progress of the six PPCR (Phase 2) activities21 under a single reporting framework 
to optimize shared learning among lead agencies and harmonize the monitoring and reporting 
of all climate change resilience initiatives in the country. A climate change results framework will 
be prepared and include baseline data, target indicators, and gender-sensitive indicators to 
measure  the  effectiveness  of  the  government’s  programs  for  strengthening  Tajikistan’s 
resilience to climate change. The framework will align with the PPCR results framework and 
build on the country’s experience in results management. The development of the  climate 
change results framework will involve all implementing agencies of the SPCR and other climate 
resilience programs, as well as civil society and development partners. The COEP will be 
responsible for coordinating the framework, with the support of the PPCR secretariat. 
 
11.  Output 5 will develop the PPCR secretariat into a national implementing entity to ensure 
that Tajikistan can use the knowledge and competences acquired in outputs 1–4 to leverage 
additional financial support and implement climate change projects beyond the life of the PPCR. 
The TA will formulate an exit strategy, endorsed by the government and including budgetary 
allocation,22 to ensure that the PPCR secretariat develops into an appropriate government unit 
with trained permanent government experts. The TA will conduct assessments, consultations,

government direct access to the Adaptation Fund, the Green Climate Fund, and other financial 
arrangements that may emerge from a post-2012 international agreement on climate change.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $6,000,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant 
basis by the ADB Strategic Climate Fund23 and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide in-kind contributions comprising personnel participation and office space with electricity, 
internet, and telephone facilities. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The executing agencies will be the COEP and Hydromet. The COEP will oversee the TA 
as a whole and be responsible for outputs 2–5. Hydromet will be responsible for output 1. The 
chair of the COEP will act as the national project director and designate two national project 
managers at the director level, one from the COEP for outputs 2–5 and one from Hydromet for 
output 1. 
 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 4 years starting in August 2012 with the mobilization of 
consultants. ADB will recruit consulting firm(s) to provide 70 person-months of international and 
397 person-months of national consulting services. In addition, ADB will recruit three individual 
consultants to provide 144 person-months of national consulting services to support the PPCR 
secretariat’s core functions. As the TA requires relatively new areas of expertise and is highly 
complex,  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  will  be  weighted  90:10  quality–cost,  and  a  full 
technical  proposal  will  be  used  in  engaging  the  consulting  firm(s).  ADB  will  engage  the 
consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time). TA disbursements will be made in accordance with the Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Required expertise includes (i) 
climate change modeling; (ii) climate risk management; (iii) climate change economics; (iv) 
capacity  building;  (v)  information  technology  and  knowledge  management;  (vi)  public 
participation, gender, and social development; (vii) communications, workshop organization, 
and training; (viii) monitoring and evaluation; and (ix) financial management and procurement. 
The consulting firm(s) will develop the operational modalities of the proposed small grant facility 
in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook and in dialogue with the 
COEP, PPCR secretariat, and local governments of the five districts selected for the preparation 
of local adaptation plans. The executing agencies will procure other inputs, including equipment, 
in accordance with ADB Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
15.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $6,000,000 to the Government of Tajikistan to be 
financed on a grant basis by the ADB Strategic Climate Fund for Building Capacity for Climate 
Resilience.

10     Appendix 3   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  A team of consultants, comprising seven international experts providing 70 person-months 
and 11 national experts providing 397 person-months, will be engaged through consulting firm(s). 
Required expertise includes (i) climate change modeling; (ii) climate risk management; (iii) climate 
change economics; (iv) institutional analysis and capacity building; (v) information technology and 
knowledge  management;  (vi)  public  participation,  gender,  and  social  development;  (vii) 
communications, workshop organization, and training; (viii) monitoring and evaluation (M&E); and 
(ix)  financial  management,  procurement,  and  fiduciary  standards.  In  addition,  three  national 
consultants will be engaged individually for 144 person-months to carry out the core functions of 
the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience (PPCR) secretariat.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference for Consultants Engaged through Consulting Firm(s) 
 
1.  Climate Change Specialist and Team Leader (international, 18 person-months) 
 
2.  The team leader will have overall responsibility for implementing the technical assistance, 
including supervising team members, reporting, financial management, the delivery of all outputs, 
and relations with the government and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The specialist will (i) 
lead the development of a climate risk management system, public awareness campaign, and 
national  climate  change  adaptation  strategy  with  detailed  priorities,  investments  needs,  and 
targets  in  key  sectors  (output  2);  (ii)  support  the  executing  agencies  in  formulating  the 
development of a PPCR M&E system (output 4); (iii) oversee the development of a training 
program and materials; (iv) operationalize a small grant facility to support the participation of 
vulnerable groups, community-based organizations, and local practitioners in formulating national 
adaptation plans in five districts; and (v) coordinate the formulation of  an exit strategy that 
institutionalizes the PPCR secretariat as government unit (output 5).  
 
2.  Climate Modeling and Impact Assessment Specialist (international, 12 person-
months) 
3.  The climate modeling specialist will have extensive knowledge of and experience in climate 
change modeling and its applications in developing countries and will (i) establish a weather 
forecast  and  climate  modeling  facility  in  the  Hydromet,  including  technical  support  to  the 
Committee of Environmental Protection (COEP) for procuring equipment; (ii) train local Hydromet 
staff on climate modeling and impact assessment; (iii) develop technical specifications for the 
equipment  to  be  procured  for  the  climate  modeling  facility;  (iv)  provide  technical  support  to 
Hydromet  for  numerical  modeling  of  local  climate  (dynamical  downscaling  of  temperature, 
precipitation, snowmelt, extreme events, and other key climatic factors) and multisector climate 
impact  assessments  and  thresholds  for  priority  sectors  (water  resources,  energy,  transport, 
agriculture, and social development) to 2100 under different emissions scenarios and for different 
time slices; (v) coordinate the development of a data and information repository and management 
system in Hydromet; and (vi) coordinate the development of a long-term strategy to hand over the 
operations of the climate modeling facility to the government, including budgetary allocation. 
 
3.  Knowledge Management Specialist (international, 9 person-months) 
4.  The  knowledge  management  specialist  will  design  and  establish  a  climate  change 
knowledge management system in cooperation with the information technology consultant for the

Appendix 3     11 
PPCR secretariat and in alignment with the PPCR communications strategy. This system will 
collect,  generate,  and  analyze  climate  change  knowledge  products  and  disseminate  them  to 
beneficiaries to enhance their awareness, provide guidance, and facilitate the mainstreaming of 
climate change in development planning. The specialist will contribute to disseminating knowledge 
generated under this technical assistance at the international, national, and community level. 
 
4.  Economist (international, 7 person-months) 
5.  The economist will (i) coordinate the integration of quantitative and qualitative economic 
assessment of climate change impacts and adaptation options in the climate risk management 
system that will be developed under output 2; (ii) provide technical support for estimating the cost 
and benefits of climate change adaptation options to be included in the national climate change 
adaptation strategy, drawing on the results of the climate change impact assessment developed 
under output 1 and international best practice; (iii) develop key economic indicators to show the 
economic consequences of different packages of adaptation policies and development projects; 
and (iv) support training and reporting. 
 
5.  Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist (international, 8 person-months) 
6.  The M&E specialist will (i) identify performance targets and indicators, including gender 
disaggregated  indicators,  for  six  PPCR  (phase  2)  activities,  in  consultation  with  the  PPCR 
secretariat  and  the  PPCR  project  teams  and  drawing  upon  indicators  already  used  by  the 
government (for example, under the poverty reduction strategy and other national and sectoral 
plans); (ii) design and support an M&E system in alignment with the PPCR results framework; (iii) 
support  the  COEP  and  the  PPCR  secretariat  in  carrying  out  annual  evaluations  of  PPCR 
performance,  including  reporting  and  supporting  independent  M&E;  and  (iv)  build  the  PPCR 
secretariat’s capacity through M&E training and technical support. 
 
6.  Infrastructure Specialist (international, 8 person-months) 
7.  The infrastructure specialist will have experience in developing engineering guidelines for 
energy,  transport,  urban  development,  irrigation,  and  water  and  a  background  in  developing 
climate change solutions. Exposure to climate change risk management is required. The expert will 
(i) support the establishment of an overarching climate risk management system for development 
projects including sector guidelines and operational manuals; (ii) produce climate proofing sector 
guidance for energy, transport, and water infrastructure; and (iii) support training and capacity 
building under output 2. 
 
7.  Financial Management and Procurement Specialist (international, 8 person-
months) 
8.  The specialist will provide technical support and guidance to the PPCR secretariat and 
executing  agencies  to  strengthen  their  capacity  in  financial  management,  procurement,  and 
administration and ensure the PPCR secretariat’s accreditation from the Adaptation Fund as a 
national implementing agency. The expert will (i) assess the financial management, administrative 
capacity, and procurement needs of the executing agencies and the PPCR secretariat; (ii) train the 
PPCR  secretariat  and  executing  agencies  on  financial  management,  procurement,  and 
administration to international standards and in accordance with the requirements of ADB and 
other multilateral development banks; (iii) support the executing agencies in the procurement of 
equipment; (iv) support the PPCR secretariat toward accreditation as a national implementing 
entity;  (v)  develop  an  exit  strategy  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of  financial  management  and 
procurement skills developed in the PPCR secretariat and executing agencies.

12     Appendix 3 
 
 
 
8.  Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist (national, 24 person-months) 
 
9.  The M&E specialist will have experience in M&E. Familiarity with indicators of climate 
change  resilience  and  adaptation  is  highly  desirable.  The  specialist  will  be  responsible  for 
implementing output 4 and for developing the PPCR  secretariat into a national implementing 
agency in coordination with the head of the PPCR secretariat, the executing agencies and PPCR 
project teams and under the guidance of the international M&E specialist.  
 
9.  Agriculture and Land Management Specialist (national, 48 person-months) 
10.  The agriculture and land management specialist will have experience in agriculture and 
sustainable land management projects in Tajikistan. Familiarity with climate change adaptation is 
highly desirable. The specialist will (i) support the implementation of PPCR activities on sustainable 
land management, in particular the PPCR (phase 2) investment project administered by the World 
Bank; (ii) support the integration of climate risk management in agriculture policies and projects 
(output 2); (iii) support the development of a national adaptation plan (output 2); (iv) support the 
development  of  local  adaptation  plans  in  five  vulnerable  districts  (output  2);  (v)  ensure  that 
information on climate change and agriculture is routinely uploaded to the knowledge management 
system that will be developed under output 3 and updated; and (vi) contribute to the identification 
of indicators and the development of an M&E framework for PPCR activities in agriculture and land 
management (output 4). 
 
10.  Water Resources Specialist (national, 48 person-months) 
11.  The water resources specialist will preferably have 5 years’ experience in water resource 
projects in Tajikistan. The specialist will be engaged full time on the staff of the PPCR secretariat 
and  report  directly  to  the  head  of  the  PPCR  secretariat.  The  specialist  will  (i)  support  the 
implementation  of  PPCR  activities  on  water  resources,  in  particular  the  PPCR  (phase  2) 
investment project administered by ADB; (ii) support the integration of climate risk management 
into water resource policies and projects (output 2); (iii) support the development of a national 
adaptation plan (output 2); (iv) support the development of local adaptation plans in five vulnerable 
districts (output 2); (v) ensure that information on climate change and water resources is routinely 
uploaded  to  the  knowledge  management  system  that  will  be  developed  under  output  3  and 
updated; and (vi) contribute to the identification of indicators and the development of an M&E 
framework for PPCR activities on water resources (output 4). 
 
11.  Energy and Transport Specialist (national, 48 person-months) 
12.  The energy and transport specialist will have experience in energy and transport projects in 
Tajikistan. The consultant will (i) support the integration of climate risk management in energy and 
transport  sector  policies  and  projects  (output  2);  (ii)  support  the  development  of  a  national 
adaptation plan (output 2); (iii) support the development of local adaptation plans in five vulnerable 
districts (output 2); (iv) ensure that information on climate change impacts on the energy and 
transport  sectors  is  routinely  uploaded  to  the  knowledge  management  system  that  will  be 
developed under output 3 and updated; and (v) contribute to the identification of indicators and the 
development of an M&E framework for PPCR activities on energy (output 4). 
 
12.  Climate Modeling Specialists (2 national, 96 person-months) 
13.  The climate modeling specialists will have experience in meteorology, weather forecasting, 
hydrology, and climate modeling in Tajikistan. They will support the establishment of a climate

Appendix 3     13 
modeling  facility  in  Tajikistan,  including  dynamic  downscaling  of  climate  change  projections, 
climate impact assessments, maintaining a management information system for weather forecast 
and  climate  data,  and  provide  technical  support  for  the  formulation  of  the  Third  National 
Communications to the United Nation Framework Convention on Climate Change as required by 
the director of Hydromet and the United Nations Development Programme. 
 
13.  Education Specialist (national, 13 person-months) 
14.  The  education  specialist  will  have  experience  in  implementing  education  projects  in 
Tajikistan and some familiarity with climate change. The specialist will, in collaboration with the 
Ministry for Education and others, introduce undergraduate and postgraduate climate science and 
glaciology modules into one or more higher education institutions in Tajikistan.    
 
14.  Glaciologist undergraduate and postgraduate (national, 6 person-months) 
15.  The glaciologist must have good knowledge of glaciers in Tajikistan and participate in 
surveys and expeditions. The glaciologist will review and contribute to studies on the impacts of 
climate change on Central Asia glaciers and develop appropriate knowledge products. 
 
15.  Public Participation and Social Development Specialist (national, 18 person-
months) 
16.  The public participation and social development specialist will have experience in facilitating 
public participation and in the gender and social dimensions of development relevant to climate 
change.  The  specialist  will  (i)  develop  a  participatory  stakeholder  analysis  and  implement  a 
communication plan to reach out to stakeholders, including disadvantaged groups such as women 
and the poor; (ii) identify gender and social development indicators for inclusion in the  M&E 
framework that will be developed under output 4; (iii) carry out surveys to assess stakeholder 
groups’ awareness of climate change; (iv) formulate guidance for government and nongovernment 
organization staff on how to consult effectively with poor and marginalized groups including women, 
address  their  concerns,  and  empower  them  to  participate  in  building  national  resilience;  (v) 
organize and hold workshops to disseminate knowledge products on the social dimension of 
climate change in Tajikistan; and (vi) support the operations of the small grant facility to ensure the 
participation of community-based organizations, vulnerable groups, and local practitioners in the 
formulation of local adaptation plans. 
 
16.  Information Technology and Knowledge Management Specialist (national, 48 
person-months) 
17.  The information technology and knowledge management specialist will have an advanced 
degree  in  information  technology  and  knowledge  management,  including  the  development  of 
multilevel websites for storing and retrieving data. Familiarity with climate change adaptation is 
highly desirable. The specialist will (i) develop and maintain a knowledge management system with 
its core in the PPCR secretariat and satellite operations in administrative districts of Tajikistan, 
including a website, district-based information centers, and other knowledge products; (ii) develop 
operational maintenance requirements for the smooth operations of the knowledge management 
network; and (iii) undertake training workshops, seminars, and focus group discussions.

14     Appendix 3 
 
 
17.  Office Manager (national, 48 person-months) 
18.  The office manager will perform support administrative, financial, and procurement tasks in 
the PPCR secretariat in accordance with ADB Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from 
time to time); translate from Russian, Tajik and English; and organize PPCR meetings and events.  
 
C.  National Consultants Engaged as Individuals 
1.  Chief Technical Advisor to the Secretariat (national, 48 person-months) 
19.  The chief technical advisor will lead the operations of the PPCR secretariat, including the 
supervision and management of PPCR  secretariat consultants. The advisor will report to the 
Government of Tajikistan’s PPCR focal point and, through that person, to the inter-ministerial 
committee. The advisor will also report to ADB regarding contract management and performance. 
The advisor will (i) develop and implement the secretariat work program in dialogue with the 
government, multilateral development banks, and other stakeholders to provide strategic direction, 
including the formulation of annual and long-term objectives, coordination, communication, and 
monitoring  and  management  plans;  (ii)  provide  technical  and  logistical  support  to  the  PPCR 
coordination mechanism, including the inter-ministerial committee, steering group, and technical 
expert group; (iii) support the development of a national adaptation strategy, local adaptation plans, 
and training and capacity building activities for national stakeholders (output 2); (iv) support the 
formulation of an M&E and reporting system (output 4), and (v) provide technical support to the 
government through attendance at international, regional, and local climate change conferences 
and events, including the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention 
on Climate Change, to disseminate Tajikistan’s knowledge, experience, and lessons learned. 
 
2.  Communications Manager for the Secretariat (national, 48 person-months) 
20.  The communications manager will support the development of a knowledge management 
system  (output  3)  to  disseminate  climate  change  information  and  reach  out  to  stakeholders, 
including women, the poor, and other marginalized groups. The consultant will (i) support the 
development of a communications strategy for the PPCR; (ii) draft press releases and develop 
newsletters and other knowledge products; (iii) manage website development, including design, 
supervision of maintenance, and updating; (iv) organize national and international conferences and 
events to disseminate PPCR outputs; and (v) manage and regularly update the PPCR stakeholder 
directory. 
 
3.  Senior Office Manager for the Secretariat (national, 48 person-months) 
21.  The  senior  office  manager  will  oversee  PPCR  secretariat  administration,  financial 
management,  and  procurement.  The  consultant  will  (i)  be  responsible  for  bookkeeping  and 
accounting for petty cash expenditures; (ii) provide logistical support to PPCR events, multilateral 
development bank missions, and project teams’ field assignments; (iii) organize the searching and 
advertising for, and the recruitment of, service providers as required in coordination with PPCR 
focal point and the secretariat manager and chief technical advisor and in concert with ADB; and 
(iv) support the executing agencies in procuring equipment.
